awd_titl_txt: RCN-UBE Incubator: Undergraduate Learning Environments in Biology
awd_abstract_narration:
The increased use of active-learning pedagogies, defined as ones that engage students in their own learning by having them participate in activities and/or discussions in class, presents unique challenges for some students. For example, active learning may cause additional stress for students with anxiety. This project will bring together experts from different fields to identify sources of anxiety in active-learning biology classrooms, design interventions to help lessen student anxiety, and to spur new research related to student anxiety in this unique context. 

This project will plan to establish a network that will bring together interdisciplinary experts in biology education research, psychiatry, psychology, and student services. The network will use the combined knowledge and experience of its members to help create more inclusive active learning biology classes for students with anxiety. Specifically, the network will identify sources of anxiety in biology courses using active-learning pedagogies, articulate best practices and design large-scale, sustainable interventions to lessen student anxiety, and coordinate future research. Although the network will focus on biology, the results of its efforts will likely be applicable in other disciplines, both in and outside of STEM. This project is being jointly funded by the Directorate for Biological Sciences, Division of Biological Infrastructure, and the Directorate for Education and Human Resources, Division of Undergraduate Education as part of their efforts to address the challenges posed in "Vision and Change in Undergraduate Biology Education: A Call to Action" (http://visionandchange/finalreport).

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
This award resulted in the successful convening of experts from different fields to identify sources of anxiety in active learning courses, design interventions to help lessen student anxiety, and spur new research related to student anxiety in this unique context.  A network of psychologists, psychiatrists, active learning biology instructors and students, student support specialists, and biology education researchers gathered to discuss the attributions of anxiety in active learning, what aspects of active learning exacerbate student anxiety, and how to alleviate anxiety within the active learning science classroom.  Below are the four questions that guided the network and their conclusions, which were developed based on network conversations informed by a thorough review of the extant literature:

 

(1) What underlies student anxiety in active learning?

Fear of failure, fear of negative evaluation, and fear of isolation are the prominent attributions of student anxiety in active learning college biology courses,

(2) What aspects of active learning affect student anxiety?

The group proposes that individual active learning activities do not exacerbate anxiety. Instead, specific decisions related to active learning (how an activity is timed, whether it's tied to points, whether it is social) may affect the aforementioned attributions and subsequently exacerbate (or alleviate) student anxiety. The group outlined specific decision points that affect anxiety in the meeting report.

(3) How do we maximize the student experience in active learning?

The group suggested that promoting a positive classroom climate, thoughtfully implementing active learning practices in ways that reduce anxiety, and equipping students with coping skills will help to maximize students’ experiences in active learning.

(4) What should be the foci for future research related to anxiety in the context of active learning science courses?

Future areas of research include studies to further elucidate the relationship between attributions and anxiety, understand how active learning is implemented, and develop and test interventions aimed to reduce anxiety in active learning. 

 

The work of the RCN-UBE Incubator: Undergraduate Learning Environments in Biology is summarized in a meeting report with 20 network members as co-authors.
